value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">15</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the pace of the speaking voice. They could not enter into</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the private world.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-espe" key="Spenser, Edmund">Spenser</rs> then --<quote source="#" rend="inline">"a little man with short hair,</quote></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">a small 
            <choice>
              <sic>vband</sic>
              <corr>band</corr>
            </choice> and cuffs"</quote> standing on the threshold of the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">"gay and sumptuous house"</quote> at <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-pens" key="Spenser, Edmund">
            <choice>
              <sic>enshurst</sic>
              <corr>Penshurst</corr>
            </choice></rs>, was separate</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">from Anon the 
            <choice>
              <sic>misntre</sic>
              <corr>minstrel</corr>
            </choice>; and from 
            <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-rhol" key="Holinshed, Raphael"><choice>
              <sic>Holmshed</sic>
              <corr>Holinshed</corr>
            </choice></rs> the Chronicler;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He was separate too from his 
            <choice>
              <sic>adueince</sic>
              <corr>audience</corr>
            </choice>. But the book which</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">had given him his 
            <choice>
              <sic>sepatare</sic>
              <corr>separate</corr>
            </choice> existence had brought into being</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a little group of readers. That audience began at once to</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">exert its pressure. What is the book that will 
            <choice>
              <sic>plase</sic>
              <corr>please</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">my patron <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-psid" key="Sidney, Philip">Sir Philip 
            <choice>
              <sic>Sidmey</sic>
              <corr>Sidney</corr>
            </choice>?</rs> What is the theme that will</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">recommend itself to the <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-eliz" key="Elizabeth I">Queen</rs>? At once come into 
            <choice>
              <sic>ecistence</sic>
              <corr>existence</corr>
            </choice> all</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">those 
            <choice>
              <sic>iunnmerable</sic>
              <corr>innumerable</corr>
            </choice> influences that are to tug and distort and</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">thwart; as too they are to stimulate and draw out. The</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">poet is no longer <del hand="ms">a homeless being</del> <add hand="ms" place="above">a nameless, a wandering voice</add>. He is surrounded <add hand="ms" place="above">[illeg.] with his audience</add></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">with an <del>
            <choice>
              <sic>atmopshere</sic>
              <corr>atmosphere</corr>
            </choice>. He subjects his inspiration</del> <add hand="ms" place="above">He is played upon by others</add> to outside</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">influences. Some are visible to himself only; others</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">only show themselves when time has past. They become more and more complex. <add hand="ms" place="inline">A</add> the book goes out into a more and more</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">numerous, a more and more divided audience.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del hand="ms">Some</del> According to its education to its wealth to its 
            <choice>
              <sic>pverty</sic>
              <corr>poverty</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the audience begins to demand what it satisfies its own needs</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Some need poetry; <del hand="ms">others</del> history; <del hand="ms">others</del> a story to make</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">them forget the drabness of their lives. The thing that</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the writer has to say becomes increasingly cumbered.</l>
